# Trump extends TikTok deadline for 4th time after reaching framework deal with China

[Politics](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics) Sep 16, 2025 6:17 PM EST

WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump formally extended the deadline to keep the social media app TikTok available in the United States until Dec. 16, giving time to complete the framework of the [deal announced Monday](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/the-u-s-says-a-deal-has-been-reached

search_results.title: TikTok Ban Timeline: How Trump Keeps Pushing the ...
search_results.text:
In [Issues Spotlight](https://nolabels.org/the-latest/category/issues-spotlight/)•September 18, 2025•5 Minutes

# TikTok Ban Timeline: How Trump Keeps Pushing the Deadline

[Peyton Lofton](https://nolabels.org/the-latest/author/peyton-lofton/)

# _Congress passed a bipartisan law to force TikTok to divest or leave the U.S., but four presidential extensions have left the ban in limbo._

President Trump quietly [extended](https://www.politico.com/news/2025/09/16/trump-extends-tiktok-deadline-again-00567058) TikTok’s divest-or-ban deadline again this week, pushing the date out to December. It’s the fourth delay since he took office – and the latest twist in a saga that started with bipartisan legislation passed nearly a year and a half ago.

A lot has happened since Congress passed the TikTok ban in April 2024. The law was meant to settle a long-running debate over whether an app owned by a Chinese company should collect data on 170 million Americans. Instead, it’s become a sign of Congre

search_results.title: TikTok lives: US, China in deal for app to keep operating in US
search_results.text:
[Skip to main content](https://www.reuters.com/www.reuters.com#main-content)

[Exclusive news, data and analytics for financial market professionalsLearn more aboutRefinitiv](https://www.reuters.com/differentiator/)

- Summary
- Companies

- Deal keeps TikTok operating in US under US-controlled ownership
- ByteDance to keep single largest ownership stake at 19.9% - sources
- Deal expected to close in 30-45 days, CNBC reports

WASHINGTON, Sept 16 (Reuters) - President Donald Trump on Tuesday announced an agreement between the U.S. and China to keep TikTok operating in the United States, with three sources familiar with the matter saying the deal was [similar](https://www.reuters.com/technology/trump-says-tiktok-deal-is-still-on-table-2025-04-09/) to one discussed earlier this year.

The agreement requires TikTok's American assets to be transferred to U.S. owners from China's ByteDance, potentially resolving a saga that has lingered for nearly a year.

search_results.title: As the 2025 TikTok ban deadline looms, here's what we know
search_results.text:
TikTok has 170 million active users in the U.S.Credit: Getty images / 5./15 WEST

[TikTok](https://mashable.com/category/tiktok) is [facing a potential ban](https://mashable.com/article/tiktok-ban-law-what-happens-next) in the U.S. that could go into effect just one day before a new administration takes the Oval Office — and its fate hinges on legal battles, political maneuvers, and President-elect Donald Trump.

## What's going on with the TikTok ban?

In short: We're waiting.

In April, President Joe Biden [signed a bill into law](https://mashable.com/article/tiktok-ban-passes-house) that gave ByteDance, [TikTok's](https://mashable.com/category/tiktok) Chinese parent company, nine months to either get a new owner or be banned in the U.S., meaning app stores like Apple and Google and internet hosting companies could face penalties from the government if they distribute or update TikTok. TikTok responded to the potential ban in the courts by suing the government in May, calling the law

Section1.Extension.  (a)  The enforcement delay specified in section 2(a) of Executive Order 14166 of January 20, 2025 (Application of Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act to TikTok), is further extended until June 19, 2025.  During this period, the Department of Justice shall take no action to enforce the Protecti

metadata.resolution: Yes, still owned by foreign adversary
metadata.title: Will TikTok still be available in the United States on December 31, 2025?
metadata.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-05-11 11:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/22559). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

Congress has passed a law requiring TikTok to shut down or sell to a non-CPC affiliated entity within 9 months, with a possible 3 month extension for a sale in progress. Original house version of the bill [here](https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/7521/text) (the senate folded it into a larger piece of legislation). In legal terms, congress is defining TikTok as a "foreign adversary controlled application". ByteDance is challenging the bill and [has indicated](https://www.reuters.com/technology/bytedance-prefers-tiktok-shutdown-us-if-legal-options-fail-sources-say-2024-04-25/) it would shut down rather than sell.

This question is about whether the service will continue to exist as a result of this bill passing, and in what form. It is possible that ByteDance will maintain ownership, for example via legal challenges to the bill. If ByteDance does comply is it not clear whether they would shut the service down or sell to a non-CPC entity.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":22559,"question_id":22559}}`
metadata.resolution_criteria:
Resolves to "Yes, still owned by foreign adversary" if TikTok is available in the US on December 31 2025, and the US app continues to be owned by ByteDance or another Chinese or foreign adversary firm contrary to the divestment written in the letter of the law. "Ownership" here is defined the way the law does, such that it is deemed to be "controlled by" a foreign adversary. If courts make a ruling about its status, that decision will apply, otherwise it will be based on reading of the law as passed. Details in fine print.

Resolves to "Yes, non-adversary owner" if TikTok is available in the US on December 31 2025, but the US app is no longer owned by ByteDance or any other firm headquartered in China, including Hong Kong or Macau but not Taiwan, or a foreign adversary. In the event that TikTok is sold to a company in another country that is deemed a US adversary, it will resolve to "Yes, still owned by foreign adversary"

Resolves to "No" otherwise.

"Available" means a video streaming app with at least 50% of the current US TikTok user base and at least 50% of the current TikTok content library is available for download to US users on the Google Play store or the Apple app store. If TikTok is renamed but these conditions hold then it is deemed "available." Changes to the TikTok algorithm do not affect this definition. The app must allow users to watch videos but changes to other app features such as users' ability to upload content or make comments do not affect this definition.
metadata.fine_print:
Quoting the law: "An entity “controlled by a foreign adversary” means an individual or entity that is:
(A) a foreign person domiciled in, is headquartered in, has its principal place of business in, or is organized under the laws of a foreign adversary country;
(B) an entity with respect to which a foreign person or combination of foreign persons described in (A) directly or indirectly own at least a 20 percent stake; or
(C) a person subject to the direction or control of a foreign person or entity described in (A) or (B)."

Definition of foreign adversary: "“Foreign adversary countries” are those specified in 10 U.S.C. § 4872(d)(2), which currently includes the Democratic People’s Republic of North Korea, the People’s Republic of China, the Russian Federation, and the Islamic Republic of Iran." The list of countries at time of resolution will be used.
options: Yes, still owned by foreign adversary
